    • Introduction to data manipulation with the tidyverse packages

Introduction to data manipulation with the tidyverse packages

maggritr, dplyr, and tidyr

Samuel Gamboa - City University of New York

Source: vignettes/articles/data_manipulation.Rmd
data_manipulation.Rmd

Introduction

This document contains a quick introduction to data manipulation using a few packages from the tidyverse: maggrittr, dplyr, and tidyr.

Packages

The following packages are needed:

library(ciatej2024)
library(palmerpenguins)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(magrittr)

The ciatej2024 package contains some datasets obtained from the airway and zebrafishRNASeq packages, which are part of the Bioconductor project. Such datasets were included here for convenience.

magrittr

Use the magrittr package to load the pipe (%>%) operator.

The pipe operator helps to:

  • Chain together the output and input of several function calls.
  • Improve code readability.

An example:

letters %>%
    head %>%
    length
#> [1] 6

R provides it’s own native pipe:

letters |> 
    head() |> 
    length()
#> [1] 6

Tidy data

Tidy data means:

  • Observations are in the rows (1 observation per row).
  • Variables are in the columns (1 variable per column).

The “palmer penguins” dataset is an example of tidy data:

penguins |>
    head()
#> # A tibble: 6 × 8
#>   species island    bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
#>   <fct>   <fct>              <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
#> 1 Adelie  Torgersen           39.1          18.7               181        3750
#> 2 Adelie  Torgersen           39.5          17.4               186        3800
#> 3 Adelie  Torgersen           40.3          18                 195        3250
#> 4 Adelie  Torgersen           NA            NA                  NA          NA
#> 5 Adelie  Torgersen           36.7          19.3               193        3450
#> 6 Adelie  Torgersen           39.3          20.6               190        3650
#> # ℹ 2 more variables: sex <fct>, year <int>

A matrix of gene expression would be an example of data that is not in “tidy” format.

zgenes_path <- system.file(
    "extdata", "zgenes.tsv", package = "ciatej2024", mustWork = TRUE
)
zgenes <- read.table(zgenes_path, sep = "\t", header = TRUE, row.names = 1)
head(zgenes)
#>                    Ctl1 Ctl3 Ctl5 Trt9 Trt11 Trt13
#> ENSDARG00000000001  304  129  339  102    16   617
#> ENSDARG00000000002  605  637  406   82   230  1245
#> ENSDARG00000000018  391  235  217  554   451   565
#> ENSDARG00000000019 2979 4729 7002 7309  9395  3349
#> ENSDARG00000000068   89  356   41  149    45    44
#> ENSDARG00000000069  312  184  844  269   513   243

dplyr

The dplyr package provides verbs (function) to manipulate data.frames (tables).

  • Filter observations (rows) and selecting variables (columns).
  • Transform (or mutate) variables.
  • Summarize data.
  • Join relational tables.

Let’s clean the palmer penguins dataset:

head(penguins_raw)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 17
#>   studyName `Sample Number` Species          Region Island Stage `Individual ID`
#>   <chr>               <dbl> <chr>            <chr>  <chr>  <chr> <chr>          
#> 1 PAL0708                 1 Adelie Penguin … Anvers Torge… Adul… N1A1           
#> 2 PAL0708                 2 Adelie Penguin … Anvers Torge… Adul… N1A2           
#> 3 PAL0708                 3 Adelie Penguin … Anvers Torge… Adul… N2A1           
#> 4 PAL0708                 4 Adelie Penguin … Anvers Torge… Adul… N2A2           
#> 5 PAL0708                 5 Adelie Penguin … Anvers Torge… Adul… N3A1           
#> 6 PAL0708                 6 Adelie Penguin … Anvers Torge… Adul… N3A2           
#> # ℹ 10 more variables: `Clutch Completion` <chr>, `Date Egg` <date>,
#> #   `Culmen Length (mm)` <dbl>, `Culmen Depth (mm)` <dbl>,
#> #   `Flipper Length (mm)` <dbl>, `Body Mass (g)` <dbl>, Sex <chr>,
#> #   `Delta 15 N (o/oo)` <dbl>, `Delta 13 C (o/oo)` <dbl>, Comments <chr>

rename

Use rename to rename variables:

dat <- penguins_raw
dat <- dat |> 
    rename(
        study_name = studyName,
        sample_number = `Sample Number`,
        species = Species,
        region = Region,
        island = Island,
        stage = Stage,
        id = `Individual ID`,
        clutch_completion = `Clutch Completion`,
        date_egg = `Date Egg`,
        culmen_length = `Culmen Length (mm)`,
        culmen_depth = `Culmen Depth (mm)`,
        flipper_length = `Flipper Length (mm)`,
        body_mass = `Body Mass (g)`,
        sex = Sex,
        delta_n = `Delta 15 N (o/oo)`,
        delat_c = `Delta 13 C (o/oo)`,
        comments = Comments
    )
colnames(dat)
#>  [1] "study_name"        "sample_number"     "species"          
#>  [4] "region"            "island"            "stage"            
#>  [7] "id"                "clutch_completion" "date_egg"         
#> [10] "culmen_length"     "culmen_depth"      "flipper_length"   
#> [13] "body_mass"         "sex"               "delta_n"          
#> [16] "delat_c"           "comments"

select

Use select to select variables or remove variables:

dat <- dat |> 
    select(
        species, island, culmen_length, culmen_depth, flipper_length,
        body_mass, sex
    )
colnames(dat)
#> [1] "species"        "island"         "culmen_length"  "culmen_depth"  
#> [5] "flipper_length" "body_mass"      "sex"

filter

Use filter to filter rows:

## There are shorter ways, but it's out of the scope of this material.
dat <- dat |> 
    filter(
        !is.na(culmen_length), !is.na(culmen_depth),
        !is.na(flipper_length), !is.na(body_mass), !is.na(sex)
    )
head(dat)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 7
#>   species       island culmen_length culmen_depth flipper_length body_mass sex  
#>   <chr>         <chr>          <dbl>        <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>
#> 1 Adelie Pengu… Torge…          39.1         18.7            181      3750 MALE 
#> 2 Adelie Pengu… Torge…          39.5         17.4            186      3800 FEMA…
#> 3 Adelie Pengu… Torge…          40.3         18              195      3250 FEMA…
#> 4 Adelie Pengu… Torge…          36.7         19.3            193      3450 FEMA…
#> 5 Adelie Pengu… Torge…          39.3         20.6            190      3650 MALE 
#> 6 Adelie Pengu… Torge…          38.9         17.8            181      3625 FEMA…

mutate

Use mutate to transform your data. It works with numeric or character variables:

dat <- dat |> 
    mutate(
        species = sub(" .+$", "", species),
        sex = case_when(
            sex == "MALE" ~ "M",
            sex == "FEMALE" ~ "F"
        ),
        body_mass = round(body_mass / 1000, 1)
    )
head(dat)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 7
#>   species island    culmen_length culmen_depth flipper_length body_mass sex  
#>   <chr>   <chr>             <dbl>        <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>
#> 1 Adelie  Torgersen          39.1         18.7            181       3.8 M    
#> 2 Adelie  Torgersen          39.5         17.4            186       3.8 F    
#> 3 Adelie  Torgersen          40.3         18              195       3.2 F    
#> 4 Adelie  Torgersen          36.7         19.3            193       3.5 F    
#> 5 Adelie  Torgersen          39.3         20.6            190       3.6 M    
#> 6 Adelie  Torgersen          38.9         17.8            181       3.6 F

group_by and summarize

Use group_by to group variables and summarize to create summaries:

dat_summary <- dat |> 
    group_by(species, island, sex) |> 
    summarize(
        mean_culmen_length = mean(culmen_length, na.rm = TRUE),
        mean_culmen_depth = mean(culmen_depth, na.rm = TRUE),
        mean_flipper_length = mean(flipper_length, na.rm = TRUE),
        mean_body_mass = mean(body_mass, na.rm = TRUE),
        n = n()
    ) |> 
    ungroup()
summary(dat_summary)
#>    species             island              sex            mean_culmen_length
#>  Length:10          Length:10          Length:10          Min.   :36.91     
#>  Class :character   Class :character   Class :character   1st Qu.:38.18     
#>  Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Median :40.59     
#>                                                           Mean   :42.58     
#>                                                           3rd Qu.:46.32     
#>                                                           Max.   :51.09     
#>  mean_culmen_depth mean_flipper_length mean_body_mass        n        
#>  Min.   :14.24     Min.   :187.2       Min.   :3.341   Min.   :22.00  
#>  1st Qu.:17.56     1st Qu.:188.8       1st Qu.:3.423   1st Qu.:23.25  
#>  Median :17.66     Median :191.8       Median :3.987   Median :27.50  
#>  Mean   :17.69     Mean   :196.6       Mean   :3.987   Mean   :33.30  
#>  3rd Qu.:18.99     3rd Qu.:198.7       3rd Qu.:4.049   3rd Qu.:34.00  
#>  Max.   :19.39     Max.   :221.5       Max.   :5.485   Max.   :61.00

count and arrange

count is a shortcut for group_by and summarize(n = n()). We can use arrange to order our data.

Let’s reorder our data to know the island with the larger number of samples:

dat |> 
    count(island) |> 
    arrange(-n)
#> # A tibble: 3 × 2
#>   island        n
#>   <chr>     <int>
#> 1 Biscoe      163
#> 2 Dream       123
#> 3 Torgersen    47

tidyr

The tidyr are provides functions to change the structure of the data. This allows to transform non-tidy data into tidy data.

  • pivot_longer changes the structure of the data to “tidy” format.
  • pivot_wider does the opposite of pivot_longer.

Using the example above (zebrafish data):

zg <- zgenes |> 
    tibble::rownames_to_column(var = "gene") |> 
    pivot_longer(
        names_to = "sample", values_to = "expr", cols = 2:last_col()
    )
head(zg)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 3
#>   gene               sample  expr
#>   <chr>              <chr>  <int>
#> 1 ENSDARG00000000001 Ctl1     304
#> 2 ENSDARG00000000001 Ctl3     129
#> 3 ENSDARG00000000001 Ctl5     339
#> 4 ENSDARG00000000001 Trt9     102
#> 5 ENSDARG00000000001 Trt11     16
#> 6 ENSDARG00000000001 Trt13    617

We can revert the operation with pivot_wider:

zg |> 
    pivot_wider(
        names_from = "sample", values_from = "expr"
    ) |> 
    tibble::column_to_rownames(var = "gene") |> 
    head()
#>                    Ctl1 Ctl3 Ctl5 Trt9 Trt11 Trt13
#> ENSDARG00000000001  304  129  339  102    16   617
#> ENSDARG00000000002  605  637  406   82   230  1245
#> ENSDARG00000000018  391  235  217  554   451   565
#> ENSDARG00000000019 2979 4729 7002 7309  9395  3349
#> ENSDARG00000000068   89  356   41  149    45    44
#> ENSDARG00000000069  312  184  844  269   513   243

Using mutate we can group by treatment and create a summary:

zg |> 
    mutate(Treatment = sub("\\d+$", "", sample)) |> 
    group_by(gene, Treatment) |> 
    summarize(
        mean = mean(expr, na.rm = TRUE),
        sd = sd(expr, na.rm = TRUE),
        n = n()
    ) |> 
    ungroup() |> 
    head()
#> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'gene'. You can override using the
#> `.groups` argument.
#> # A tibble: 6 × 5
#>   gene               Treatment  mean    sd     n
#>   <chr>              <chr>     <dbl> <dbl> <int>
#> 1 ENSDARG00000000001 Ctl        257. 113.      3
#> 2 ENSDARG00000000001 Trt        245  325.      3
#> 3 ENSDARG00000000002 Ctl        549. 125.      3
#> 4 ENSDARG00000000002 Trt        519  633.      3
#> 5 ENSDARG00000000018 Ctl        281   95.7     3
#> 6 ENSDARG00000000018 Trt        523.  62.9     3

dplyr (again) - Joining tables

dplyr provide *join functions to merge related tables based on one or more variables.

For example, they airway dataset from the “airway” package on Bioconductor.

Import the data (a copy is provided in this package):

dat_types <- c("sample", "gene", "expr")
names(dat_types) <- dat_types
airway <- lapply(dat_types, \(x) {
    fpath <- system.file(
        "extdata", paste0("airway_", x, "_data.tsv"),
        package = "ciatej2024", mustWork = TRUE
    )
    read.table(
        file = fpath, header = TRUE, sep = "\t"
    ) |> 
        as_tibble()
})
lapply(airway, head)
#> $sample
#> # A tibble: 6 × 9
#>   Run        SampleName cell   dex   albut avgLength Experiment Sample BioSample
#>   <chr>      <chr>      <chr>  <chr> <chr>     <int> <chr>      <chr>  <chr>    
#> 1 SRR1039508 GSM1275862 N61311 untrt untrt       126 SRX384345  SRS50… SAMN0242…
#> 2 SRR1039509 GSM1275863 N61311 trt   untrt       126 SRX384346  SRS50… SAMN0242…
#> 3 SRR1039512 GSM1275866 N0526… untrt untrt       126 SRX384349  SRS50… SAMN0242…
#> 4 SRR1039513 GSM1275867 N0526… trt   untrt        87 SRX384350  SRS50… SAMN0242…
#> 5 SRR1039516 GSM1275870 N0806… untrt untrt       120 SRX384353  SRS50… SAMN0242…
#> 6 SRR1039517 GSM1275871 N0806… trt   untrt       126 SRX384354  SRS50… SAMN0242…
#> 
#> $gene
#> # A tibble: 6 × 10
#>   gene_id   gene_name entrezid gene_biotype gene_seq_start gene_seq_end seq_name
#>   <chr>     <chr>     <lgl>    <chr>                 <int>        <int> <chr>   
#> 1 ENSG0000… TSPAN6    NA       protein_cod…       99883667     99894988 X       
#> 2 ENSG0000… TNMD      NA       protein_cod…       99839799     99854882 X       
#> 3 ENSG0000… DPM1      NA       protein_cod…       49551404     49575092 20      
#> 4 ENSG0000… SCYL3     NA       protein_cod…      169818772    169863408 1       
#> 5 ENSG0000… C1orf112  NA       protein_cod…      169631245    169823221 1       
#> 6 ENSG0000… FGR       NA       protein_cod…       27938575     27961788 1       
#> # ℹ 3 more variables: seq_strand <int>, seq_coord_system <lgl>, symbol <chr>
#> 
#> $expr
#> # A tibble: 6 × 9
#>   gene_id      SRR1039508 SRR1039509 SRR1039512 SRR1039513 SRR1039516 SRR1039517
#>   <chr>             <int>      <int>      <int>      <int>      <int>      <int>
#> 1 ENSG0000000…        679        448        873        408       1138       1047
#> 2 ENSG0000000…          0          0          0          0          0          0
#> 3 ENSG0000000…        467        515        621        365        587        799
#> 4 ENSG0000000…        260        211        263        164        245        331
#> 5 ENSG0000000…         60         55         40         35         78         63
#> 6 ENSG0000000…          0          0          2          0          1          0
#> # ℹ 2 more variables: SRR1039520 <int>, SRR1039521 <int>

One dataset needs to be converted to tidy format:

airway$expr <- airway$expr |> 
    pivot_longer(
        names_to = "Run", values_to = "expr", cols = 2:last_col()
    )
head(airway$expr)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 3
#>   gene_id         Run         expr
#>   <chr>           <chr>      <int>
#> 1 ENSG00000000003 SRR1039508   679
#> 2 ENSG00000000003 SRR1039509   448
#> 3 ENSG00000000003 SRR1039512   873
#> 4 ENSG00000000003 SRR1039513   408
#> 5 ENSG00000000003 SRR1039516  1138
#> 6 ENSG00000000003 SRR1039517  1047

Now we can use `dplyr::left_join’ to merge these datasets:

merged_data <- airway$expr |> 
    left_join(airway$gene, by = "gene_id") |> 
    left_join(airway$sample, by = "Run")
head(merged_data)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 20
#>   gene_id         Run        expr gene_name entrezid gene_biotype gene_seq_start
#>   <chr>           <chr>     <int> <chr>     <lgl>    <chr>                 <int>
#> 1 ENSG00000000003 SRR10395…   679 TSPAN6    NA       protein_cod…       99883667
#> 2 ENSG00000000003 SRR10395…   448 TSPAN6    NA       protein_cod…       99883667
#> 3 ENSG00000000003 SRR10395…   873 TSPAN6    NA       protein_cod…       99883667
#> 4 ENSG00000000003 SRR10395…   408 TSPAN6    NA       protein_cod…       99883667
#> 5 ENSG00000000003 SRR10395…  1138 TSPAN6    NA       protein_cod…       99883667
#> 6 ENSG00000000003 SRR10395…  1047 TSPAN6    NA       protein_cod…       99883667
#> # ℹ 13 more variables: gene_seq_end <int>, seq_name <chr>, seq_strand <int>,
#> #   seq_coord_system <lgl>, symbol <chr>, SampleName <chr>, cell <chr>,
#> #   dex <chr>, albut <chr>, avgLength <int>, Experiment <chr>, Sample <chr>,
#> #   BioSample <chr>

Using dplyr verbs:

airway_summary <- merged_data |> 
    select(gene_name, dex, expr) |> 
    group_by(gene_name, dex) |> 
    summarise(
        mean = mean(expr, na.rm = TRUE),
        sd = sd(expr, na.rm = TRUE),
        n = n()
    )
head(airway_summary)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 5
#> # Groups:   gene_name [3]
#>   gene_name dex      mean     sd     n
#>   <chr>     <chr>   <dbl>  <dbl> <int>
#> 1 5S_rRNA   trt   0.00962 0.0981   104
#> 2 5S_rRNA   untrt 0.0288  0.218    104
#> 3 7SK       trt   0.292   0.798     48
#> 4 7SK       untrt 0.104   0.371     48
#> 5 A1BG      trt   6       2.94       4
#> 6 A1BG      untrt 9       2.16       4
